statement.text: Compression ultrasound is the primary diagnostic modality for DVT. The diagnosis is made when a vein fails to compress fully under transducer pressure. Normal veins collapse completely; thrombosed veins show incompressibility with echogenic material. Sensitivity is 94-97% for proximal DVT; lower (63-75%) for isolated calf vein thrombosis.
statement.formal: DVT Ultrasound Diagnosis: Incompressibility = DVT | Normal vein: complete collapse under pressure | Thrombosed vein: fails to compress | Sensitivity: 94-97% proximal, 63-75% distal | Specificity: 94-99%

explanation.intuition: A healthy vein is like a soft tube - when you press on it, it flattens completely. A vein with a clot is like a tube with a marble inside - no matter how hard you press, you can't flatten it completely. Ultrasound lets us watch this in real-time, making it easy to see if a vein is open (compresses) or blocked (doesn't compress).
explanation.key_insight: Compression ultrasound is so good at diagnosing proximal DVT that a negative study in a patient with high clinical suspicion should prompt serial imaging. The test is less reliable for calf vein DVT - if clinical suspicion is high and proximal veins are negative, either repeat in 5-7 days or do whole-leg imaging.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: Linear transducer (5-12 MHz) in transverse orientation. Apply firm pressure at 1-2 cm intervals from CFV to popliteal vein. Complete compression (anterior and posterior walls touch) = normal. Partial or no compression = DVT. Additional findings: echogenic material in lumen, increased vein diameter, loss of respiratory phasicity, absence of flow augmentation with calf squeeze. Proximal-only vs whole-leg: Proximal (CFV, SFV, popliteal) is quicker; whole-leg includes calf veins but has lower sensitivity. Serial strategy: if proximal negative on day 0, repeat day 5-7 to catch propagating calf DVT.
common_misconceptions: Visible thrombus is required - incompressibility is the criterion, not visualization
Negative ultrasound rules out DVT - false negatives occur, especially for calf DVT
Doppler is essential for diagnosis - compression is sufficient, Doppler is supplementary
Old DVT looks the same as new - chronic DVT may show partial compressibility, wall thickening

definitions_glossary.compression_ultrasound: Technique using transducer pressure to assess vein collapse
definitions_glossary.incompressibility: Failure of vein to collapse completely under pressure
definitions_glossary.proximal_dvt: Thrombus in popliteal vein or above
definitions_glossary.distal_dvt: Thrombus in calf veins only (below popliteal)

examination_technique.patient_position: Supine, leg externally rotated, knee slightly flexed
examination_technique.orientation: Transverse for compression, longitudinal for Doppler
examination_technique.compression_intervals: Every 1-2 cm along course of veins

indeterminate: Partial compressibility (may indicate old or resolving thrombus)
Technically limited study (obesity, edema, overlying wounds)

proximal_plus_serial.approach: Proximal veins only; repeat in 5-7 days if negative
proximal_plus_serial.rationale: Catches propagating calf DVT before it becomes proximal

whole_leg_single.rationale: Single test, identifies all DVT, but calf DVT management controversial

definition.@value: Primary diagnostic imaging modality for DVT using compression to assess vein patency

sources.citation: American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria for Suspected Lower-Extremity DVT.
Goodacre S, et al. Systematic review and meta-analysis of the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonography for deep vein thrombosis. BMC Med Imaging. 2005;5:6.

learning_objectives: Interpret ultrasound findings for DVT diagnosis
Explain the difference between proximal-only and whole-leg strategies
Understand limitations of ultrasound for calf vein DVT
clinical_pearls: Incompressibility = DVT, even if you can't see the thrombus
Proximal sensitivity is excellent, calf sensitivity is limited
If negative but suspicious, repeat in 5-7 days or do whole-leg
Chronic DVT may show partial compressibility with wall thickening

medicalCode.description: Duplex scan of extremity veins, complete bilateral study
